title: Morgan Morgan-Owen
text:
Morgan Maddox Morgan-Owen <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a> ( – 14 August 1950) was a Welsh amateur <a href="association%20football">footballer</a> who played in the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> for <a href="Glossop%20A.F.C.">Glossop</a> and <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a> as a <a href="wing%20half">wing half</a>. He won 12 caps and scored two goals for <a href="Wales%20national%20football%20team">Wales</a> between 1897 and 1907 and had a long career with each of the tour leading amateur clubs of the period, <a href="Corinthian%20F.C.">Corinthian</a> and <a href="Casuals%20F.C.">Casuals</a>.
Personal life.
Morgan-Owen's brother <a href="Hugh%20Morgan-Owen">Hugh</a> was also a Welsh international footballer. He was educated at Colet School, <a href="Shrewsbury%20School">Shrewsbury School</a> and <a href="Oriel%20College%2C%20Oxford">Oriel College, Oxford</a> and gained an <a href="honours%20degree">honours degree</a> in Modern History from the latter institution. After the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, he continued his career as a schoolteacher at <a href="Repton%20School">Repton School</a> (1909–1937) and also served as <a href="Her%20Majesty%27s%20Diplomatic%20Service">diplomatic</a> private secretary. He married in 1925 and had three children.
First World War.
Morgan-Owen enlisted in the <a href="Essex%20Regiment">Essex Regiment</a> in 1905 and served as a <a href="major">major</a> with the regiment during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>, seeing action at <a href="Gallipoli%20Campaign">Gallipoli</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Langemarck%20%281917%29">Langemarck</a>, <a href="Battle%20of%20Cambrai%20%281917%29">Cambrai</a> and the <a href="German%20spring%20offensive">German spring offensive</a>. He also had two periods attached to the <a href="Rifle%20Brigade%20%28The%20Prince%20Consort%27s%20Own%29">Rifle Brigade</a>, the second as a temporary <a href="lieutenant%20colonel">lieutenant colonel</a> commanding the 10th (Service) Battalion. He was awarded the <a href="Distinguished%20Service%20Order">DSO</a> in August 1918 for "conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty. On the occasion of the <a href="German%20Army%20%28German%20Empire%29">enemy</a> attack, when his battalion was in reserve, he moved it up to resist the attack and held on to the position for two days, though the troops on his flank were pressed back. His steadfast determination to hold his ground against repeated attacks and under heavy fire largely contributed to restoring and keeping in hand the critical situation which had arisen". Morgan-Owen was wounded and gassed during the war and an injury to his arm resulted in the end of his sporting career.
